answer_variants.answer: Angular is a popular open-source web application framework developed by Google for building mobile and desktop web applications.

Angular is a comprehensive, TypeScript-based structural framework for building dynamic single-page applications (SPAs). It provides a complete set of tools for handling everything from data binding and routing to dependency injection.

Angular is a platform and framework for building single-page client applications using HTML and TypeScript. It implements core and optional functionality as a set of TypeScript libraries that you import into your applications.
A TypeScript-based open-source framework for front-end web development, primarily used for building Single Page Applications (SPAs).

Angular is like a pre-assembled toolkit for building a house. Instead of buying every tool separately, it gives you everything you need—a hammer, saw, and drill—all designed to work perfectly together.
A Google-maintained TypeScript framework for building robust web apps.

Unlike libraries like React, Angular is a full-fledged 'batteries-included' framework. It enforces a specific architectural pattern based on components, services, and modules, and includes built-in solutions for HTTP, routing, and form management.
Angular is a tool that helps developers make websites that feel like fast mobile apps, where you don't have to wait for pages to reload.
Angular is an opinionated ecosystem that leverages a class-based component hierarchy and a reactive programming model (via RxJS) to manage asynchronous state and DOM reconciliation efficiently.
A component-based framework for building scalable web applications, providing a collection of well-integrated libraries and a suite of developer tools.
A component is a block of code that controls a part of the screen (the UI) and contains the logic for it.
Components are the fundamental building blocks of an Angular application. They consist of a TypeScript class with a @Component decorator, an HTML template, and CSS styles.
An Angular component is a directive with a template. It manages a patch of screen called a view and is defined by metadata in the @Component decorator.
The basic building block of Angular UI; identified by @Component decorator.
A component is like a Lego brick. You build your whole application by snapping together different bricks (like a header brick, a button brick, etc.) to create a complete structure.
The basic UI building block combining logic, template, and styles.

Technically, a component is a TypeScript class that interacts with an HTML template via data binding. It has a lifecycle managed by Angular, allowing developers to hook into events like initialization or destruction.
It's a small, reusable part of your website, like a navigation bar or a search box, which has its own design and behavior.
Components are the leaf nodes or branches of the Angular injector tree, facilitating granular state management and encapsulated view logic through Shadow DOM or Emulated encapsulated styles.
A class that is decorated with @Component to define the UI and behavior of an application element.
It's the way Angular syncs the data in your code with what the user sees on the screen.

Data binding is a core concept that allows synchronization between the model and the view. Angular supports four types: String Interpolation, Property Binding, Event Binding, and Two-way Data Binding.
A mechanism for coordinating parts of a template with parts of a component. Use [property] for input, (event) for output, and {{expression}} for interpolation.
The automatic synchronization of data between model and view components.
It's like a live link between a spreadsheet and a chart. If you change a number in the sheet (the code), the chart on the screen updates automatically without you doing anything else.
Syncing data between the component class and its template.

Angular's data binding simplifies DOM manipulation by eliminating the need for manual updates. Property binding flows data into elements, while event binding feeds user actions back into the class logic.
It means you don't have to keep track of every HTML tag; when you change a variable in your code, the webpage updates by itself.
Data binding in Angular is realized through the change detection cycle, where the framework monitors bound expressions for value changes and updates the DOM accordingly during the digest loop.
A technique for linking data from the component's model to its view.
It's a decorator that groups together related components, directives, pipes, and services into a functional unit.

NgModule is a class decorated with @NgModule which acts as a container for a cohesive block of code. It declares the components that belong to it and exports some of them so other modules can use them.

A module decorator that takes a metadata object which includes properties like 'declarations' (for UI classes), 'imports' (other modules needed), 'providers' (services), and 'bootstrap' (the main component).
A decorator function used to define a module class that contains components, services, and other elements.
Think of NgModule as a package or a box that holds everything needed for a specific feature. For example, a 'UserAccount' box would contain the login screen, the sign-up screen, and the user service.
A decorator defining the compilation context and dependencies of a module.
NgModules configure the injector and the compiler. They help organize an application into cohesive blocks of functionality, which is essential for lazy loading and code modularity.
It's basically a way to tell Angular: 'Here is all the stuff that goes together for this part of my app.'

While Standalone Components are the new standard, NgModules still serve as the foundation for legacy apps and library packaging, providing a centralized way to handle dependency injection and component visibility.
A decorator that identifies a class as an Angular module and provides its metadata.
Directives are instructions in the HTML that tell Angular how to change the appearance or behavior of DOM elements.

Directives are classes that can modify the structure or attribute of an element. There are three types: Components (directives with templates), Structural Directives (*ngIf, *ngFor), and Attribute Directives (ngClass, ngStyle).
A marker on a DOM element (such as an attribute, element name, or comment) that tells Angular's HTML compiler to attach a specified behavior to that DOM element.
Categories: Component, Structural, and Attribute. Marked with '@Directive'.
If HTML is the noun (a paragraph, a div), a directive is like an adjective or a verb. It can say 'make this paragraph RED' or 'show this div ONLY if the user is logged in'.

answer_variants.one_liner: Classes that add behavior or structure to HTML elements.

answer_variants.answer: Structural directives change the DOM layout by adding or removing elements (prefixed with an asterisk), while Attribute directives change the appearance or behavior of an existing element (like ngClass).
They are special keywords you put inside your HTML tags to make them smarter, like making a list automatically repeat itself.

Attribute directives leverage HostBinding and HostListener to interact with the host element, allowing for encapsulated logic that reacts to user interactions at the DOM level without modifying the component template directly.
A class that can modify the appearance or behavior of an HTML element in an Angular template.
It is a way to display dynamic text from the TypeScript file to the HTML template using double curly braces: {{ }}.
String interpolation is a one-way data binding technique. It allows us to embed expressions into HTML templates. Angular evaluates the expressions and inserts the resulting string into the DOM.
A mechanism that incorporates dynamic values into the template using the 'double-mustache' syntax. It is restricted to read-only data flow from component to view.
Expression syntax {{ }} used for one-way data binding of strings.
It's like a placeholder in a form letter. You write 'Hello {{name}}', and when the letter is sent, '{{name}}' is replaced with a real name like 'John'.
Displaying data in templates using {{ expression }}.
Angular replaces the expression with a string value of the corresponding component property. It can handle simple calculations, but shouldn't be used for complex logic which belongs in the class.
It's the easiest way to show a variable's value on your webpage—just put the variable name inside double curly brackets.
While simple, interpolation is susceptible to performance hits if used with getter functions or heavy computations, as it's re-evaluated on every change detection cycle.
A context-dependent mechanism for resolving and embedding values into a text fragment.
Property binding allows you to set the value of an HTML element's property (like a button's 'disabled' state) using a variable from your code.
Property binding is used to pass data from a component's class to a property of an HTML element in the view. It uses square brackets: [property]="value".
A one-way data binding mechanism from data source to view target. It sets a property of a DOM element, component, or directive.
Syntax: [target]="expression". One-way binding from component to DOM.
It's like a remote control for an appliance. You press a button on the remote (change a variable in code), and the appliance's setting (the HTML property) changes to match.
Setting DOM properties using [property]="value" syntax.

Unlike interpolation, property binding keeps the type of the value (like a boolean or an object), which is essential when binding to component inputs or complex DOM properties like 'src' or 'disabled'.
It helps you control things like images or buttons from your code—for example, making a button 'click-proof' until a form is filled out.
Property binding is the primary tool for unidirectional data flow in Angular, ensuring that child components are configured by parent data without side effects during the change detection pass.
A one-way data binding technique to set properties of target elements.
It's how the user communicates with the code. It listens for actions like clicks or keystrokes and runs a function in response.
Event binding is used to handle user interactions such as button clicks, mouse movements, or keystrokes. It flows data from the view to the component. Syntax: (event)="statement()".
Unidirectional data flow from the view to the data source. It uses parentheses to wrap the event name and binds it to a handler in the component class.
Syntax: (targetEvent)="handler()". View-to-source data flow.
It's like a doorbell. When a visitor (the user) presses the button (the click), it triggers a chime in the house (the function in your code).
Handling user actions using (event)="handler()" syntax.
Event binding allows custom events from child components (via EventEmitter) or standard DOM events. It provides access to the event object using the special '$event' variable.
When you want something to happen after a user clicks a button, this is the tool you use to connect the button to your logic.
Event binding is decoupled from the DOM. Angular's EventManager handles the registration and cleanup, which is crucial for preventing memory leaks in single-page applications.
A one-way binding from the view to the component triggered by user events.
It's a combination of property and event binding that keeps the model and the view perfectly in sync at all times.
Two-way data binding allows data to flow in both directions: from class to template and vice versa. It is primarily used in forms and is implemented using 'ngModel'. Syntax: [(ngModel)]="property".
Bidirectional synchronization where the view property updates the model and the model updates the view property. Achieved using the banana-in-a-box syntax.
Syntax: [(target)]="expression". Synchronizes model and view.
It's like Two people editing a shared document. If person A (the code) changes a word, person B (the user) sees it immediately. If person B types a new word, person A gets that update instantly.
Mutual sync between view and model using [(ngModel)].
Two-way binding uses a specific pattern: a property 'x' and an event 'xChange'. Angular provides 'ngModel' as a convenient directive to handle this for input elements.
It means if you type something into an input field, the variable in your code changes automatically to match what you typed.
While convenient, two-way binding can lead to complexity in state management. Large scale apps often prefer reactive forms or state libraries for better predictability and debugging.
A mechanism to exchange data from component to view and from view to component.
It is a command-line tool that helps you create, develop, test, and build Angular applications quickly.

Angular CLI (Command Line Interface) is the official development tool for Angular. It simplifies tasks like project initialization, adding new files (components, services), and managing the build process across different environments.
A command-line interface tool to initialize, develop, scaffold, and maintain Angular applications directly from a command shell. It encapsulates Webpack and other build tools.
Official tool for scaffolding and building Angular apps; core commands start with 'ng'.
The CLI is like a sophisticated 3D printer for your app. Instead of sewing every piece of a shirt yourself, you just type a command and it prints a perfectly structured component ready to be used.
Official command-line tool for Angular development.

The CLI manages the entire development lifecycle, including linting, testing, and production optimization (AOT, tree-shaking). It follows best practices by automatically creating test files and properly registering components.
It's a helper tool where you type short commands like 'ng new' or 'ng generate' to do all the boring setup work for you.
CLI can be extended with Schematics, allowing teams to create custom blueprints for standardizing shared components or architectural patterns across large organizations.
A command-line interface for Angular, used to scaffold and build applications.
